main_text:
Reductionism encompasses a set of ontological, epistemological, and
methodological claims about the relations between different scientific
domains. The basic question of reduction is whether the properties,
concepts, explanations, or methods from one scientific domain
(typically at higher levels of organization) can be deduced from or
explained by the properties, concepts, explanations, or methods from
another domain of science (typically at lower levels of organization).
Reduction is germane to a variety of issues in philosophy of science,
including the structure of scientific theories, the relations between
scientific disciplines, the nature of explanation, the diversity of
methodology, and notions of theoretical progress, as well as to
numerous topics in metaphysics and philosophy of mind, such as
emergence, mereology, and supervenience.

Questions about reduction in biology are pervasive throughout the
history of philosophy and science. Many contemporary debates have
historical analogues that reflect long-standing controversies about
the legitimacy of reductionist research strategies and modes of
explanation used by different life science subdisciplines. In
philosophy of biology, debates about reduction in the second half of
the 20th century focused traditionally on the question of whether and
in what sense classical genetics can be reduced to molecular biology
(although other strands of discussion were present, such as whether
evolutionary theory is inherently anti-reductionist because of the
principle of natural selection). Philosophical debates now address a
wider array of domains beyond genetics (e.g., development, ecology,
evolution, cell biology, and neuroscience), and include additional
questions about the nature and status of interdisciplinarity, such as
the integration of data or standards across biological fields.

Section 1 gives an overview of the idea of reduction and how it
connects to biological domains and other philosophical issues. Since
debates about reductionism have been going on long before recent
discussions in philosophy of biology, Section 2 offers some historical
background. Section 3 reviews the main philosophical accounts of
reduction in light of their respective motivations and limitations.
More general objections to the feasibility or scientific relevance of
reduction are discussed in Section 4. Because most philosophical
discussions during the past two decades have largely focused on other
models of the structure of scientific knowledge than reduction (e.g.,
integration), Sections 5 and 6 concentrate on these recent issues and
trends.
